title: 108_hr268
content: The "United States Weather Research Program Act of 2003" focuses on hurricanes, floods, heavy precipitation, improving weather forecasts, quick progress in impactful areas, leveraging resources for collaborative scientific efforts, and providing research grants to universities and research institutions. The United States Weather Research Program focuses on improving forecasts for hurricanes, heavy precipitation, floods, and two-to-fourteen day forecasting through better prediction of timing, location, and intensity, as well as conducting research to fill observational gaps in the Northern Hemisphere. The United States Weather Research Program aims to improve forecasts for various weather events and fill observational gaps in the Northern Hemisphere through the THORpex experiment and advanced data assimilation techniques. Additionally, the program focuses on assessing societal and economic impacts of adverse weather, delivering weather information effectively, and testing research concepts at test bed centers. The United States Weather Research Program aims to improve forecasts and fill observational gaps through experiments and data assimilation techniques. Testing research concepts at test bed centers is also a key focus for technology transfer to operational meteorologists. The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration leads the US Weather Research Program, coordinating with other federal agencies and entities to develop a five-year plan for weather research, dissemination of information, and transferring research results to forecasting operations. Reporting requirements are also outlined. The Administrator of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration must provide annual reports to specific congressional committees, detailing the five-year plan, funding sources, any plan changes, and an assessment of plan objectives. Authorization of appropriations for the Office of Atmospheric Research of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration includes $15 million for fiscal year 2004, $15.5 million for fiscal year 2005, and $16 million for fiscal year 2006, with at least 50% allocated for grants to institutions of higher education.
